title: What is the most abundant element in the universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: After the big bang, the vast majority of baryonic matter was hydrogen (I am stating baryonic matter here to differentiate the matter which we would consider as chemical elements against dark matter - which it seems that most of the universe is made of). Over time, this hydrogen collected in the first stars where fusion allowed for the creation of heavier elements. Hydrogen is still the main fuel for stars during their main sequence. Most of the baryonic matter in the universe seems to be main sequence stars. Therefore, most of the baryonic matter in the universe is still hydrogen.

After 13.8 miliards years after the Big Bang it is still hydrogen which dominates elements composition of the Universe. It is followed by helium. The remaining 90 or so chemical elements are produced in stars and constitute only a few percent of the overall mass.http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/cosmos/C/chemical+composition

Q. What is the most common of elements? In the universe, hydrogen. On earth, oxygen (99% of it is tied up in silicate minerals). Hydrogen isn’t the most common element on Earth because the Earth is too small to keep elemental hydrogen, and there isn’t enough water (the other major way hydrogen occurs in the universe) to outweigh the oxygen. See Abundance of the chemical elements - Wikipedia

One would think Nitrogen since it’s 70% of our air but air is only present in so many places. The ocean certainly is lacking in it, so i’d say Carbon. Every life form has it & inorganic Carbon is just as omnipresent considering how often we find it in minerals, rocks, geodes and the like.

We clearly cannot be sure. Logically it should Hydrogen, the simplest: a proton with an one electron orbiting around it. All elements were built out of the energy that preceded all matter. Stars manufacture heavy elements out of lighter ones. So stars start as light elements. In the visible universe it is Hydrogen still.

The top 5 most common elements are : Hydrogen (H) = > 750,000(PPM)Helium (He) = > 240,000(PPM)Oxygen (O) = > 10,000(PPM)Carbon (C) = > 5,000(PPM)Neon (Ne) = > 1,300(PPM)PPM : Parts Per Million I hope you got your answer…
Hydrogen is the most abundant element in Universe. In terms of number of atoms-92% Hydrogen atoms In terms of mass-72% Hydrogen

Depends on your frame of reference. In the universe it is: Hydrogen, Helium, Oxygen, Carbon and Neon. One Earth it is: Iron, Oxygen, Silicon, Magnesium and Sulphur. Depending on how you phrase this question, you can get a lot of different answers!
This is a good source for technical data of elements: Abundance in the Universe for all the elements in the Periodic Table
What two elements is the universe made primarily of? Actually, there are four primary elements: matter, energy, dark matters, and dark energy.

The neutrons formed as it cooled decayed into protons and electrons and as it cooled below plasma temperature they condensed to hydrogen atoms and some helium. Hydrogen vastly dominates the matter budget, always has, always will. Stars have little effect on that.
In order of abundance h he li be bo c n o fe ne na mg al si s cl ar k ca. Somebody please confirm.
